questions.topic: Margin drivers / shrink / damages / media network
questions.question: Shrink represented approximately 3.3% of sales in FY2023, a 100+ basis point headwind to gross margin—what specific operational interventions (locked cases, staffing hours, EAS tagging, store layout changes) are showing measurable shrink reduction in pilot stores, and what is the timeline and capital required to scale these initiatives across the fleet?
questions.why_it_matters: Shrink is the single largest margin pressure point and management has acknowledged it will take multiple years to remediate; understanding which levers are working and their scalability is critical to modeling gross margin recovery.

questions.topic: SG&A drivers / labor / store manager turnover
questions.question: Store manager turnover improved in 2023 but remains elevated versus pre-pandemic levels—can you quantify the fully-loaded cost of store manager turnover (recruiting, training, productivity loss) and detail how the recent wage investments and 'Back to Basics' initiative are translating into retention metrics by tenure cohort?
questions.why_it_matters: High turnover drives both direct SG&A costs and indirect impacts on shrink, in-stocks, and customer experience; proving ROI on labor investments is essential for margin bridge credibility.

questions.question: With SNAP benefits normalized post-pandemic and your core customer (household income under $35K) facing persistent inflation in rent and utilities, what leading indicators are you tracking to gauge wallet share retention, and how are you adjusting promotional intensity or assortment to defend traffic?
questions.why_it_matters: Approximately 25-30% of Dollar General transactions involve SNAP; understanding demand elasticity and competitive switching behavior among this cohort is key to revenue forecasting.

questions.question: You reduced SKU count by approximately 1,000 items in 2023 as part of simplification efforts—what was the sales transfer rate on discontinued SKUs, and how are you balancing further rationalization against the risk of losing destination trips in discretionary categories?
questions.why_it_matters: SKU reduction can improve in-stocks and labor productivity but risks alienating customers if core items are cut; quantifying transfer rates validates the strategy's revenue neutrality.

questions.topic: Store productivity / new store returns / remodels
questions.question: New store productivity has declined as you've expanded into more rural and lower-density trade areas—what is the current four-wall EBITDA payback on 2022-2023 vintage stores versus the historical 2-year target, and how are you adjusting site selection criteria or format mix (pOpshelf, DGX) to protect returns?
questions.why_it_matters: With 800+ annual openings, even modest payback slippage has material capital efficiency implications; validating unit economics underpins the growth algorithm.

questions.question: Dollar Tree's multi-price rollout and Walmart's aggressive price investments have intensified competitive pressure—how are you using your pricing analytics capabilities to identify and defend key value items (KVIs), and what is the gross margin trade-off of matching competitor price points on traffic-driving consumables?
questions.why_it_matters: Price perception drives traffic in discount retail; understanding the margin cost of competitive response is essential for modeling the gross margin trajectory.

questions.question: DG Media Network revenue grew double digits in 2023 and carries accretive margins—what is the current revenue run rate, how are you expanding advertiser demand beyond CPG partners, and what investments are required to scale first-party data capabilities to compete with Walmart Connect?
questions.why_it_matters: Retail media is a high-margin growth vector that can partially offset shrink headwinds; sizing the opportunity and investment needs informs EBITDA bridge assumptions.

questions.topic: Margin drivers / shrink / damages / media network
questions.question: Damages and markdowns on perishables have increased as you've expanded cooler count—what is the current shrink and waste rate in fresh/frozen categories versus ambient consumables, and how are you optimizing ordering algorithms and store-level execution to improve turns?
questions.why_it_matters: Cooler expansion is a strategic priority to drive traffic but introduces execution complexity; isolating perishable shrink informs the true margin contribution of the fresh initiative.

questions.topic: SG&A drivers / labor / store manager turnover
questions.question: Self-checkout penetration has increased but has been cited as a shrink contributor—what is the current mix of transactions through self-checkout, and are you considering pulling back SCO in high-shrink stores as competitors have done?
questions.why_it_matters: SCO is a labor productivity lever but may exacerbate shrink; understanding the trade-off informs both SG&A and gross margin modeling.

questions.topic: Store productivity / new store returns / remodels
questions.question: The DG Fresh self-distribution network now serves the majority of stores—what is the current cost-per-case advantage versus third-party distribution, and what incremental capital is needed to complete the remaining rollout and optimize routing efficiency?
questions.why_it_matters: DG Fresh is a structural cost advantage but required significant upfront investment; validating ongoing savings and remaining capex informs free cash flow projections.

parsed_response.topic_coverage: All seven required topics are addressed: margins/shrink (Q1, Q8), SG&A/labor/turnover (Q2, Q9), inventory/SKU (Q4), store productivity/new stores/remodels (Q5, Q10), pricing/markdowns/competition (Q6), digital/delivery (Q7), and low-income consumer/SNAP exposure (Q3).
parsed_response.methodology_notes: Questions were prioritized based on (1) materiality to near-term earnings and valuation, (2) management's stated strategic priorities and known pain points from recent earnings calls, and (3) ability to elicit quantifiable, actionable responses rather than qualitative narratives. Shrink and labor were ranked highest given their outsized impact on the FY2024 margin bridge; SNAP/consumer and competitive dynamics followed due to top-line risk; digital/media network and supply chain were included as emerging value drivers.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Reviewed Dollar General Q4 FY2023 earnings release, FY2024 guidance commentary, and recent 10-K to identify key financial drivers (shrink, SG&A deleverage, comp sales softness).
Step 2: Scanned industry news (Reuters, CNBC, Retail Dive, WSJ) for competitive context (Dollar Tree multi-price, Walmart price investments, self-checkout theft concerns).
Step 3: Mapped identified issues to required topic areas and drafted questions that probe root causes, quantify impacts, and request forward-looking metrics.
Step 4: Ranked questions by materiality to EBITDA and strategic relevance, ensuring balanced coverage across all mandated topics.
